title: An innovative strategy for overcoming ultra-high ammonia nitrogen inhibition on anaerobic methanogenesis via stepwise domestication - Microbiome
description: Background The world is facing both an increasingly severe energy crisis and a growing problem of agricultural pollution. The utilization of agricultural waste by anaerobic digestion (AD), has received increasing attention. AD using representative waste cow dung results in total ammonia nitrogen (TAN) accumulation and inhibition of methanogens resulting in reduced CH4 production. However, there is a lack of highly efficient in-situ biological domestication strategies to enhance the TAN tolerance of methanogens in AD systems. Results In this study, an incremental approach to gradually increasing the TAN concentration has been used for overcoming the problem. The results showed that at an ultra-high concentration of 6124.09 mg/L TAN, a 48-day domesticated AD system functioned stably and the cumulative CH4 production reached 72.81 mL/g volatile solids, whereas the undomesticated AD system failed to produce CH4. After domestication, the lactate dehydrogenase concentration decreased to 96.44 ng/L and the adenosine triphosphate concentration increased to 48.77 nmol/L, confirming that microbial activity improved. Hydrolytic and acidogenic bacteria were enriched, with Methanosarcina (79.73%) dominating the domesticated AD system, primarily Methanosarcina mazei. Metagenomic analysis showed that with two-component system enrichment, the key inhibited steps from glycerate-1,3P2 to pyruvate (2.498‰), and from acetyl-CoA and acetyl phosphate to acetic acid (1.141‰ and 0.798‰), as well as vital methanogenic genes mcrA (0.128‰), mcrB (0.127‰), and mcrG (0.065‰), were both enriched, which favored a stable methanogenic system. More importantly, this ultra-high resistance AD system also showed the potential to increase the CH4 production per unit substrate at the Minhe biogas plant with 24,000 m3 operation scale in Shandong Province, China. Conclusions Stepwise increase the TAN concentration is a novel method that was demonstrated to be a practical and sustainable way to overcome ultra-high TAN inhibition (6124.09 mg/L). During domestication, the two-component system may regulate the microbial collaborative network to ensure microbial activity and high abundance enrichment, thus potentially constructing a methanogenic system dominated by hydrogenotrophic and acetoclastic methanogenesis, holding a promising application prospect. This study helped recognize the potential of methanogens in tolerating ultra-high inhibition and developed an achievable AD technology for robustly treating fecal residue and wastewater in practice.
content:
Source of waste activated sludge, cow dung, and engineering samples

The WAS was taken from the wastewater treatment plant in Yangling District, Shaanxi Province. China. Tap water was added to adjust the total solid and volatile solid to 3.79% and 2.06%, respectively. The total carbon and total nitrogen of the dried WAS were 24.46% and 3.64%, respectively. The CD was collected from the Animal Science Experiment Station of Northwest A&F University, and the total solid and volatile solid were 15.11% and 11.35%, respectively. The total carbon and total nitrogen of dried CD were determined to be 39.02% and 2.24%, respectively. The pH of WAS and CD were 8.50 and 7.45, respectively.

In order to explore the engineering application potential of the TAN domesticated AD system, its samples were compared with the samples of the 24,000 m3 Minhe biogas plant. The biogas plant information is shown in Table 1. The biogas plant investigated in this study is located in Shandong Province, China and has realized an ultra-high TAN load with CH4 production. The concentration of NH4+-N, and chemical oxygen demand (COD) were 5688.32 and 32,690 mg/L, respectively. The total solid, volatile solid, total carbon, and total nitrogen and pH of the engineering samples were 10%, 9%, 4.74%, 0.66%, and 6.7, respectively.

Experimental device and procedure

The 500 mL fermenter was used for AD in batch mode (Fig. 1). The total solid of the AD system was 6%, and the working volume was 300 mL at 55 °C. In the TAN domestication group (TDG), the initial TAN concentration is set at 1000 mg/L, which is then incrementally increased to 2000, 3000, 4000, 5000, and 6000 mg/L, respectively. The gradually increasing NH4+-N concentration corresponds to stages 1–6 of the TAN domestication process, respectively. Since the peak CH4 production period in these AD systems conclude within 8 days, each stage is designed to last 8 days, resulting in a total Duration of 48 days. At the end of each stage, a 50 mL AD mixture was retained as inoculum and inoculation into the fermenter used for the next stage. The final working volume of TDG in stages 2–6 was 350 mL.

A control check group (CKG) was established to assess the alleviation effect of TAN suppression in TDG. The experimental procedure for CKG was the same as that for TDG, except that no NH4+-N was added. Additionally, at the sixth stage, a TAN inhibition group (TIG) with 350 mL working volume that had not been domesticated to tolerance TAN was set up. In TIG, 5400 mg/L of NH4+-N was artificially introduced to achieve a TAN concentration of 6000 mg/L and to verify the TAN suppression effect, determining whether TDG had alleviated TAN suppression. Samples were extracted from all fermenters every 2 days to measure NH4+-N, COD, CH4, and volatile fatty acids (VFAs), and the pH value was adjusted to about 6.45–7.0 by using 4 mol/L NaOH or HCl. Three parallel fermenters were set up for each of TDG, CKG, and TIG.

Evaluation of inhibitory effect of total ammonia nitrogen in various stages of anaerobic digestion process

The AD process was divided into four stages: hydrolysis, acidogenesis, acetic acid production, and CH4 production. However, due to the mutual influence of the metabolic processes in each stage, it was difficult to specifically evaluate the inhibitory effect of TAN at each stage. Therefore, dextran, glucose, sodium butyrate, and sodium acetic acid were used as model substrates to evaluate the effect of TAN on metabolic processes by comparing the specific degradation rates of the AD substrates (each model compound) [27].

Hydrolysis test

This test was used to evaluate the effect of TAN on the hydrolysis process During co-AD. In this experiment, 30 mL of the mixture was taken from the fermenters of CKG, TIG, and TDG and added to nine fermenters respectively, and then 270 mL of tap water was added to ensure that the final volume of the mixture was 300 mL. The dextran concentration in each fermenter was 5000 mg/L. The pH of the mixture in all fermenters was adjusted to 6.5 with 4 mol/L HCl. The TAN concentration of TDG and TIG was adjusted to about 6000 mg/L using NH4Cl, whereas no NH4Cl was added in CKG. All fermenters were purged with nitrogen for 5 min to remove internal oxygen to ensure an anaerobic environment and substrate concentrations were determined after 2 days incubation at 55 °C.

Acidogenic test

This test was used to evaluate the effect of TAN on the acidogenic process. In addition to 5000 mg/L glucose was used instead of dextran, and the experimental process was consistent with the hydrolysis test.

Acetogenesis test

This test was used to assess the impact of TAN on the acetogenesis process. The operation of this test was performed with the same approach as described in the hydrolyzed test except the dextran was replaced by 5000 mg/L sodium butyrate.

Acetoacetic methanogenesis test

This test was in order to analyze the effect of TAN on the acetoacetic methanogenesis process During the AD system. The operation of this test was performed with the same approach as described in the acetogenesis test except sodium butyrate was replaced by 5000 mg/L sodium acetic acid.

Assessment of microbial activity in anaerobic digestion systems

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and adenosine triphosphate (ATP) concentrations were measured on days 8, 16, 24, 32, 40, and 48 of the AD process of TAN domestication process, representing cell membrane damage and microbial energy in CKG and TDG, respectively. The concentration of LDH and ATP in TIG was measured on day 8.

DNA extraction, polymerase chain reaction, and high-throughput sequencing

From stage 1–6, the biofilms collected in CKG were designed CKG1, CKG2, CKG3, CKG4, CKG5, and CKG6, respectively. Similarly, the biofilms collected from the TDG system were designed TDG1, TDG2, TDG3, TDG4, TDG5, and TDG6. The biofilms were collected from the TAN inhibition group and the Minhe biogas plant engineering AD system, and were designated TIG and EAD, respectively. The total DNA was extracted by LC-Bio Technology Co., Ltd. (Hangzhou, Zhejiang, China). For amplification of bacterial 16S rRNA gene regions V3 + V4 and archaeal DNA, specific primers were used 338 F (ACTCCTACGGGAGGCAGCAG) and 806R (GGACTACHVGGGTWTCTAAT) for bacteria, and 524F10extF (TGYCAGCCGCCGCGGTAA) and Arch958RmodR (YCCGGCGTTGAVTCCAATT) for archaea. The bacterial polymerase chain reaction (PCR) mixture (20 µL) contained 4 µL of 5 × FastPfu buffer, 2 µL of 2.5 mM dNTPs, 0.8 µL of each primer (5 µM), 0.2 µL of BSA, 0.4 µL of FastPfu polymerase, and 10 ng of template DNA. The archaeal PCR mixture (20 µL) included 10 µL of 2 × Pro Taq, 0.8 µL of each primer (5 μM), and 10 ng of template DNA. PCR cycling conditions were: initial denaturation at 95 °C for 3 min; eight cycles of denaturation at 98 ℃ for 15 s, annealing at 60 ℃ for 15 s, and extension at 72 ℃ for 30 s; and then final extension at 72 ℃ for 5 min. Finally, we performed the 2 × 150 bp paired-end sequencing on an Illumina Novaseq 6000 (LC-Bio Technology Co., Ltd.) following the manufacturer’s protocol.

Metagenomic sequencing, genome assembly, gene prediction, taxonomy, and functional annotation

To elucidate the domestication mechanism, TDG1, TDG2, TDG3, TDG4, TDG5, and TDG6 were subjected to metagenomic sequencing. Also, CKG and TIG were sequenced for comparative analysis. The DNA was fragmented into about 400 bp fragments using Covaris M220 equipment (Gene Company Limited, Hong Kong, China) during the preparation of paired-end libraries. Library construction was performed using the NEXTFLEX Rapid DNA-Seq kit (Bioo Scientific, Austin, TX, USA). Paired-end sequencing was performed on an Illumina NovaSeq platform at Majorbio Bio-Pharm Technology Co., Ltd. in Shanghai, China, using the NovaSeq 6000 S4 Reagent Kit v1.5 (300 cycles) per the manufacturer’s instructions, with all procedures conducted in triplicate. After sequencing, paired-end Illumina reads were preprocessed with adaptor trimming and removal of low-quality reads (length < 50 bp, quality value < 20 or containing N bases) using fastp (version 0.20.0). Metagenomic data were assembled into contigs of at least 300 bp using MEGAHIT [28]. Open reading frames (ORFs) were predicted within each contig using Prodigal [29]/MetaGene[30], and ORFs ≥ 100 bp were extracted and translated into amino acid sequences using the NCBI translation table. A non-redundant gene catalog was created with CD-HIT (version 4.6.1) [31] at 90% sequence identity and coverage. Gene abundance was assessed by aligning high-quality reads to the non-redundant gene catalog using SOAPaligner [32] with a 95% identity threshold. For classification annotation, Diamond (version 0.8.35) [33] was used to compare representative sequences in the non-redundant gene catalog with the NR database and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes annotation with an e-value threshold of 1e−5.

Analytical methods

COD and NH4+-N were determined by the standard methods [34]. Total carbon and total nitrogen were measured by the elemental analyzer. The total solid and volatile solid were measured by the weight loss method. pH is measured with a pH meter (PHS-3C, LEICI, Shanghai, China). The determination of VFAs and CH4 was consistent with published methods [35], and the total VFAs was the sum of the measurement value of acetic, propionic, butyric, and valeric acids. The concentration of LDH and ATP were analyzed with an assay kit from Shanghai Enzyme-linked Biotechnology Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). The concentration of TAN was calculated as STAN × 10pH/(Kb/Kw + 10pH), where STAN represents the concentration of NH3-N + NH4+-N, Kb is the ionization constant of the ammonia equilibrium equation and Kw is the ionization constant of water. Kb/Kw was calculated as e6344/(273+T) (with T of 55 °C during this experiment) [36]. Electric conductivity was measured by a conductivity meter (DDS-11A, Youke, Shanghai, China). Construct correlation networks to explore the interactions between genera as well as the interactions between genera and environmental factors [37]. The supplementary materials outline the validation methods for assessing the potential of key methanogenic pathways, as well as the methods for binning analysis.

Statistical analysis

All samples were assayed in triplicate, and the standard deviation analysis and significance testing (t test) were conducted using Origin 2021. Significance was evaluated by t test: **P < 0.01 and *P < 0.05.

Results and discussion

Assessment of anaerobic digestion performance during total ammonia nitrogen domestication process

In order to evaluate the TAN tolerance at various stages of AD caused by the TAN domestication process, the hydrolysis, VFAs production, and CH4 production process were continuously monitored. The concentration of NH4+-N and FA determines the inhibition of AD process. As shown in Fig. 2a, substrates released more NH4+-N in AD process, resulting in the average NH4+-N concentration of 691.34 to 799.81 mg/L in CKG. Its maximum FA was 22.94 mg/L, mainly due to the stable pH. In TDG, the initial NH4+-N concentration was 945.42 mg/L. With the addition of NH4+-N in the AD process, the average NH4+-N concentration gradually increased from 1194.82 mg/L in the first stage to 6005.99 mg/L in the sixth stage, along with FA ranging from 38.28 to 118.09 mg/L, significantly higher than CKG (P < 0.05, Fig. S1a, b). Previous studies have shown that FA concentration greater than 300 mg/L will cause significant toxicity inhibition of microorganisms [36], indicating that FA in this experiment did not cause serious inhibition on microbial activity. Therefore, CKG did not exhibit inhibitory effects but TDG was inhibited when TAN exceeded 1000 mg/L.

The hydrolysis performance of the AD process can be evaluated by monitoring COD concentration. As shown in Fig. 2b, the COD concentration in CKG was up to 2609.74 mg/L in the first stage, which was similar to TDG at 2715.38 mg/L, but the COD concentration decreased to 2403.21 and 2497.44 mg/L at the end of this stage, respectively. The hydrolysis of macromolecular organic substances leads to an increase in COD concentration; however, methanogenic archaea consume the biodegradable organic matter, resulting in a decrease in COD concentration [38]. It is worth noting that the COD concentration of TDG was always significantly higher than that of CKG in subsequent stages 2–6 (P < 0.05, Fig. S1c). FA has been shown to promote the decomposition of substrates [17], which was one of the reasons for the higher COD concentration in TDG. The continuously increasing electric conductivity in Fig. 2c also confirms the ongoing hydrolysis (P < 0.05, Fig. S1d).

The acidogenic performance of the AD process can be assessed by monitoring the VFAs. As shown in Fig. 2d–f, the VFAs peak in the first stage of CKG and TDG reached 293.44 and 208.70 mg/L, and then decreased to 224.39 and 190.28 mg/L, respectively, showing similar VFA production performance. However, in the second stage, VFAs in TDG were up to 728.92 mg/L, whereas VFAs in CKG were only 306.48 mg/L, indicating that VFAs began to accumulate due to TAN inhibition. Figure 2c shows that the concentration of COD in TDG was higher than that in CKG, indicating that VFAs were produced from excessive organic matter but the CH4 production process was TAN inhibited, leading to VFAs accumulation. At the end of the second stage, the VFAs concentration of CKG and TDG decreased to 87.26 mg/L and 113.77 mg/L, respectively, indicating that TDG can utilize VFAs without causing a large amount of VFAs accumulation. The similar phenomenon also occurred in the subsequent stages 3–6 (Fig. S1e). It should be noted that the VFAs in CKG were mainly acetic acid and other VFAs remained in low concentrations. The accumulation of VFAs, particularly acetic acid, is primarily due to the inhibition of their downstream metabolic conversion pathways.

Further, we evaluated the CH4 production performance. As shown in Fig. 2g, in the first stage in CKG, CH4 production peaked at 43.37 mL/g VS whereas in TDG it peaked at 48.01 mL/g VS. However, in the second stage, the CH4 production in TDG was less with a maximum of only 37.99 mL/g VS being lower than the 52.07 mL/g VS in CKG, indicating that the CH4 production activity was inhibited by ultra-high TAN concentrations, which explains the accumulation of VFAs. The inhibition of TAN on TDG also appeared in the subsequent stages 3–6. It is important to note that the AD process is always accompanied by the release of H2. However, both the daily H2 production and cumulative H2 production in CKG were lower than those in TDG (Fig. S2), indicating that H2 may be used by hydrogenotrophic methanogenesis. Figure 2h shows that the CH4 accumulation of CKG in stages 3–6 was stable between 113.41 and 126.75 mL/g VS, whereas that of TDG was stable between 72.81 and 88.40 mL/g VS. The stable accumulation of CH4 in stages 3–6 confirms the stability of the TDG. Therefore, although it was lower than CKG, a continuous and stable TAN tolerance system was achieved in the TAN domestication process to achieve CH4 production under ultra-high TAN concentration.

To verify the tolerance performance of TDG, the TIG with 6000 mg/L TAN and without TAN domestication was compared. As shown in Fig. 2, although the average concentration of NH4+-N (5964.27 mg/L) and FA (98.22 mg/L) was similar to the concentration TDG, its COD concentration (3276.15 to 4923.02 mg/L) and VFAs (247.76 to 1606.28 mg/L) remained higher, indicating that the organic matter utilization was inhibited. In addition, the concentrations of acetic acid, propionic acid, butyric acid and valeric acid in TIG were 790.43, 433.99, 182.55, and 6.59 mg/L, respectively, indicating that its acetogenic process was more significantly inhibited by TAN than TDG and CKG. The accumulated high concentration of VFAs will also synergistically inhibit the methanogenesis process with an ultra-high concentration of TAN [39]. As a result, TIG could not produce CH4, so it is not included in Fig. 2h.

Therefore, although the AD performance of TDG was slightly weaker than that of CKG, the AD system with ultra-high TAN (6124.09 mg/L) tolerance and stable CH4 production through TAN domestication was achieved. This technology has the potential to break through the bottleneck of synergistic inhibition of TAN and VFAs caused by AD of raw materials containing ultra-high TAN concentration.

Evaluation of the inhibitory effect of total ammonia nitrogen on different stages of anaerobic digestion process

In order to verify whether TAN only inhibits the acetogenic and methanogenesis process rather than the hydrolysis process, degradation analysis of model substrates at various stages of the AD process was performed. Macromolecular substances can only be further utilized by microorganisms after being hydrolyzed into small molecules. Dextran was used as the model substrate (Fig. 3a). Its removal rate of TDG and TIG with 6000 mg/L TAN were 97.21% and 98.72%, respectively, whereas that of CKG was 100% without TAN. The hydrolysis performance of the three groups was similar, indicating that the hydrolysis process was little affected. Glucose could be used to produce VFAs, representing acidogenic process (Fig. 3b). The glucose removal rates of TIG and TDG with 6000 mg/L TAN were 98.57% and 98.66%, respectively, which were similar to 98.61% of CKG without additional TAN, indicating that the acidogenic process was less affected. After glucose is metabolized, it is first converted into butyric acid, which serves as a precursor of acetic acid and indirectly affects methanogenic potential [40]. Using sodium butyrate as a model substrate can help determine the acetate production efficiency and verify whether it limits methanogenesis. As shown in the Fig. 3c, the removal rate of sodium butyrate in CKG was 99.57%, whereas that of TDG was only 83.52%, and that of TIG was 73.89% (P < 0.05), indicating that the acetic acid production process was inhibited, and the acetic acid production performance of TDG was better than that of TIG. Further, acetic acid can be used as the main substrate in the methanogenic process of methanogenesis, and the effect of TAN on this process was also evaluated (Fig. 3d). The removal rate of sodium acetic acid in CTG and TDG was 84.42% and 73.38%, which was better than TIG without TAN domestication (P < 0.05), indicating that TAN would lead to the inhibition of acetoclastic methanogenesis, whereas domestication could improve its tolerance. The inhibitory effect of TAN on the methanogenesis process was stronger than that on the acetogenic process. In addition, acetate, H2 and methanol are key substrates for the methanogenic process and the CH4 production from their metabolism can be used for a detailed assessment of the potential for these pathways. However, CH₄ can only be produced when acetate and H₂ are used as substrates in TDG, yielding 7.40 and 8.58 mL of CH₄, respectively, whereas methanol does not produce any CH₄ (Fig. S3). This indicates that hydrogenotrophic methanogenesis primarily contribute to CH4 production, followed by acetoclastic methanogenesis.

Therefore, TAN mainly inhibited the methanogenic process, followed by the acetogenic process, but the tolerance of AD to ultra-high concentrations of TAN was achieved through TAN domestication.

Microbial activity in anaerobic digestion system

Microbial activity directly affects the performance of acetogenic and methanogenesis processes. The enzymes involved in microbial activity and energy provision were tracked. LDH, an intracellular enzyme and a marker for cell membrane integrity, indicates whether microorganisms are under stress from toxic substances [41]. As shown in Fig. 4a, the average concentration of LDH in TDG was 96.44 ng/L during the TAN domestication process, which was higher than that of CKG (86.72 ng/L), which confirmed that FA might lead to the leakage of LDH. However, the LDH concentrations of both TDG and CKG continued to decrease, and the damage to the microbial system was gradually reduced, indicating that TAN domestication could improve tolerance. According to the comparison of LDH concentration regression equation, it could be seen that the tolerance of TDG can be achieved faster. The LDH concentration at stage 4 was similar to that in the first stage of CKG, indicating that TAN domestication not only improved tolerance but even conferred the potential of TDG to surpass CKG. ATP is involved in energy transfer between microorganisms and can characterize the activity of microbial systems [42]. ATP in CKG showed obvious advantages (Fig. 4b), and its average ATP concentration was 53.55 nmol/L, which was also higher than that in TDG (48.77 nmol/L), indicating that TAN had a certain inhibitory effect on microbial activity. During the TAN domestication process, the ATP concentrations of CKG and TDG continued to increase, and the metabolic activity of the microbial system gradually increased, indicating that the metabolic activity was also enhanced while the tolerance of the microbial system was improved. From the ATP concentration regression equation, it is evident that the growth rate of TDG activity was faster and the ATP concentration in the stage 4 was consistent with the CKG concentration. In order to verify the acclimation effect, TIG was tested. The LDH and ATP of TIG were 97.71 ng/L and 42.74 nmol/L, respectively, with TAN inhibition, which showed higher cytotoxicity and lower energy than CKG and TDG. This suggests that TAN can lead to low CH4 production by inhibiting microbial activity of acetogenic microorganisms and methanogenic microorganisms. Therefore, although TAN induced cytotoxicity and reduced energy levels in microorganisms, the TAN domestication process can enhance the adaptability of microorganisms to TAN, thereby reducing stress responses. This is another reason for maintaining the continuous production of CH₄.

Bacterial community responses to total ammonia nitrogen domestication process

The hydrolysis and acidogenesis processes in the AD system are primarily regulated by the bacterial community, necessitating analysis. As shown in Fig. 5a, the dominant bacteria in CKG were mainly composed of MBA03_unclassified (12.43% to 18.46%) and Limnochordia_unclassified (7.72% to 15.82%). MBA03_unclassified was closely related to Izemoplasmatales_unclassified (Fig. 5b), a group with known organic degradation properties [43], indicating that MBA03_unclassified might function in hydrolysis. Limnochordia_unclassified, related to D8A-2 [44], is likely involved in acidogenesis. Additionally, the detected Fibrobacterales_unclassified [45] (2.48% to 8.20%) and HN-HF0106 [46] (1.80% to 8.04%) are known to participate in acetic acid production. Firmicutes_unclassified (3.38% to 9.00%) has the ability to produce acetic acid in collaboration with other taxa [47]. The subdominant genera Caldicoprobacter (1.27% to 3.24%) [48] and DTU014_unclassified (1.36% to 2.22%) [49] are also recognized to possess potential for acetic acid production with tolerance to TAN stress. Therefore, the main role of CKG was hydrolysis and acetic acid production, and bacteria could interact with each other through synergistic network.

In TDG, the dominant microbial community is mainly composed of MBA03_unclassified (21.20% to 24.52%) and Limnochordia_unclassified (6.67% to 11.29%), along with genera with hydrolytic and acetogenic potential Proteinivoracales_unclassified [50] (2.56% to 3.82%), Caldicoprobacter (2.20% to 3.23%), and Treponema [51] (2.00% to 3.43%). The stable enrichment of MBA03_unclassified, Caldicoprobacter, and Limnochordia_unclassified proved that TAN domestication reshaped a dominant bacterial community with good stability. Additionally, Firmicutes_unclassified (1.41% to 2.48%), Haloplasma (0.40% to 2.86%), and DTU014_unclassified (1.00% to 1.24%) also occupy a subdominant position, accompanied by the enrichment of Proteiniphilum [52] (0.96% to 3.36%) and Synergistaceae_unclassified [53] (0.98% to 1.69%), which have been confirmed to possess acidogenic potential. The detection of a symbiotic genus Synergistaceae_unclassified indicated that symbiotic relationships might also occur [53]. Although the decrease in the abundance of acetogenic bacteria confirmed the lower acetogenic performance of TDG than CKG, but the detection of the dominant acetogenic bacteria confirmed that TDG had the potential to produce acetic acid.

In TIG, the microbial community structure changed significantly, mainly composed of Bacillus [54] (9.92%) and Halocella [55] (5.51%), which have been confirmed to possess hydrolytic and acidogenic potential. Also, Treponema (4.10%), MBA03_unclassified (3.53%), Firmicutes_unclassified (1.86%), and Caldicoprobacter (1.55%) were less abundant, which confirmed the conclusion that can be drawn from Fig. 3 that the acetogenic process was inhibited. The TAN domestication process enriched MBA03_unclassified, Limnochordia_unclassified, Proteinivoracales_unclassified, Caldicoprobacter, Firmicutes_unclassified, and Treponema to ensure the hydrolysis and acetogenic process. Collaboration might be the main way for microbial community function under TAN inhibition.

An important question is what are the characteristics and driving factors of microbial collaboration. The correlation network between environmental factors and microorganisms was revealed. In CKG (Fig. 5c), although FA alone had a positive correlation with Proteinivoracales_unclassified, Clostridium, and MBA03_unclassified, these three genera had positive cross-correlations with other genera. The effect of FA on these three genera would thus extend to a broader microbial community, including Izemoplasmatales_unclassified, Proteiniphilum, DMER64, Tepidiphilus, Haloplasma, Caldicoprobacter, Fastidiosipila, Synergistaceae_unclassified, Treponema, Halocella, D8A-2_unclassified, Fermentimonas, and Hydrogenophaga. This positive correlation can be attributed to the adaptation of low-concentration FA by the microbial synergistic network. The release of nitrogen during the hydrolysis process may also contribute to this significant positive correlation. In addition, there was a negative correlation between the FA and another microbial community, which was composed of Rhodothermaceae_unclassified, HN-HF0106, Limnochordia_unclassified, Fibrobacterales_unclassified, and Firmicutes_unclassified, indicating the TAN sensitivity of these genera. In TDG (Fig. 5d), one collaborative network was composed of Synergistaceae_unclassified, Caldicoprobacter, Proteiniphilum, Fermentimonas, Ruminococcaceae_unclassified, Bacillus, DMER64, Rhodothermaceae_unclassified, Halocella, DTU014_unclassified, Limnochordia_unclassified, and HN-HF0106. There was a significant correlation with FA and NH4+-N, indicating that the microbial community might be resistant to ultra-high concentrations of TAN, which belonged to the dominant microbial community under ultra-high TAN conditions. Compared with CKG, the change of microbial collaborative network in TDG was not only affected by FA, but also by NH4+-N. The association of Synergistaceae_unclassified, Caldicoprobacter, Proteiniphilum, Fermentimonas, and DMER64, which are involved in the construction of coexisting networks, did not change, indicating that they were the key functional genera under TAN tolerance.

Overall, the driving factors of the microbial collaborative network in the TAN domestication process was confirmed as FA and NH4+-N. Microorganisms might adapt to ultra-high concentrations of TAN through changes in the synergistic mode, thus enriching the acetogenic and hydrolytic genus.

Archaeal community responses to total ammonia nitrogen domestication process

The change in archaeal communities and abundance affecting CH4 production need further explored. As shown in Fig. 6a, the dominant genus in CKG was Methanosarcina [56] (52.33% to 87.05%), which can produce CH4 through hydrogenotrophic, acetoclastic, and methylotrophic processes. The subdominant community was composed of hydrogenotrophic methanogens Methanoculleus [19] (3.10% to 15.45%), Methanobacterium [57] (2.75% to 12.36%), Methanobrevibacter [58] (0.15% to 0.84%), and Methanocorpusculum [59] (0.09% to 2.83%). There were also some acetoclastic methanogens Methanothrix [60] (1.52% to 4.09%) and Methanosarcinales_unclassified [61] (0.38% to 0.60%). The continuous inoculation process as illustrated in Fig. 1 promoted an increase in the abundance of Methanosarcina in CKG, which provides a crucial prerequisite for the feasibility of TAN domestication in TDG. Table S1 lists the dominant methanogen species under the taxonomic classification of dominant methanogen genera, and metagenomic binning analysis confirms that Methanosarcina mazei is the key species in the archaeal community (Fig. S5).

Also, Methanosarcina (51.55–79.73%) was the dominant genus in TDG, and the secondary dominant archaea community is mainly composed of hydrogenotrophic genus Methanoculleus (5.20% to 27.34%), Methanobacterium (1.67% to 6.94%), Methanobrevibacter (0.07% to 0.55%), and Methanocorpusculum (1.03% to 6.08%). In addition, there were acetoclastic methanogens Methanothrix (1.47% to 3.38%) and Methanosarcinales_unclassified (0.24% to 0.66%). This is considered to be a reason for the reduction in organic matter concentrations, achieved through the enrichment of methanogens that produce CH4 from acetic acid. It is worth noting that the TAN domestication process could increase the abundance of Methanosarcina under the ultra-high TAN concentration condition, indicating that TAN domestication successfully constructed a compound methanogens pathway that could tolerate TAN. The community structure at the species level found to follow a similar trend, confirming the dominance of Methanosarcina (Fig. S4a). Further metagenomic binning analysis identified that the key archaeal species enriched in TDG is Methanosarcina mazei (Fig. S5, Table S1), which is consistent with that in CKG.

However, there were differences in the archaea community in TIG, mainly Methanosarcina (34.93%), and the secondary archaea community was mainly hydrogenotrophic methanogens Methanoculleus (11.86%), Methanobacterium (18.43%), Methanobrevibacter (1.24%), and Methanocorpusculum (10.30%). Only Methanothrix (7.13%) was found to be an acetoclastic methanogen. The low abundance of Methanosarcina and acetoclastic methanogens in TIG indicates that AD would be inhibited by TAN without TAN domestication, which was consistent with the conclusion in Fig. 2. In Fig. 6a, the abundance of hydrogenotrophic methanogens in TIG was higher than that in TDG and CKG, but it failed to produce CH4. This would have been mainly due to the lack of H2 as a substrate supply (Fig. S2a). In addition, Fig. 4 reveals that TAN may lead to low activity of bacteria and archaea in AD system, which was also one of the reasons. Therefore, the abundance of the dominant Methanosarcina had an enrichment trend similar to that of CH4 production, indicating it may be a potential key genus regulating CH4 output. However, the key methanogenic pathways with high contribution still need to be identified in combination with gene abundance.

A key question is do archaea communities also have symbiotic relationships driven by NH4+-N and FA. As shown in Fig. 6b, the archaea community in CKG was composed of Methanobacterium, Methanocorpusculum, Methanoculleus, Methanothrix, Methanomicrobia_unclassified, Methanomicrobiaceae_unclassified, and Methanobrevibacter. There is a complex material exchange and symbiotic relationship between methanogens [62], and their collaborative network is also regarded as an organic symbiotic network, and such similar interactions are also reflected at the species level (Fig. S4b). In addition, the collaborative network in TDG at the genus level is mainly composed of Methanobacterium, Methanobrevibacter, Methanomicrobiaceae_unclassified, Methanothrix, Methanocorpusculum, Methanosarcinales_unclassified, Methanomicrobia_unclassified, and Methanoculleus (Fig. 6c), which is similar to the network at the species level (Fig. S4c). However, this archaea community was negatively correlated with TAN and Methanosarcina, confirming that Methanosarcina can withstand ultra-high TAN levels.

Therefore, the collaborative network of archaea was also driven by FA and NH4+-N, but Methanosarcina could tolerate TAN without the collaborative network.

Effect of total ammonia nitrogen Domestication on acetic acid production process

It is important to know in which vital step TDG achieves tolerance to TAN in acetogenic process. Glycolysis is the primary acetogenic pathway, as shown in Fig. 7. Glucose was degraded to α-glucose-6P by crr, malX, and ptsG gene products after being actively transported into cells, but total abundances of these genes in TIG were 0.019‰, which were similar to 0.022‰ of TDG6 and 0.011‰ of CKG1. This indicated that this pathway of TDG and TIG were both uninhibited. In addition, α-d-glucose-1P can be degraded to α-d-glucose by glucose-1-phosphatase encoded by the agp and yihX genes, and then to β-d-glucose by aldose 1-epimerase encoded by galM. However, the abundances of agp, yihX, and galM genes in TIG were higher than those in TDG6 (0.002‰, 0.072‰, and 0.585‰) and CKG1 (0.002‰, 0.078‰, and 0.519‰), with values of 0.003‰, 0.092‰, and 0.626‰, respectively. This suggests that the step from α-d-glucose-1P to β-d-glucose is not inhibited.

α-d-glucose-1P can also be degraded to α-glucose-6P by phosphoglucomutase encoded by pgm and pmm-pgm genes. The abundance of pmm-pgm in TIG (0.283‰) was inhibited by TAN, which was lower than that in CKG1 (0.347‰) and TDG6 (0.309‰). Subsequently, α-d-glucose-6P was degraded into β-d-glucose-6P by repressed genes GPI, pgi1, tal-pgi, and pgi-pmi genes encoding glucose-6-phosphate isomerase. However, the abundances of pgi1, tal-pgi, and pgi-pmi genes in TIG were 0.069‰, 0.039‰, and 0.058‰, respectively, which were lower than those in TDG6 (0.109‰, 0.040‰, and 0.085‰) and CKG1 (0.114‰, 0.073‰, and 0.089‰). It is worth noting that the high abundance of genes of TDG in these processes were responsible for the realization of tolerance.

There were also pathways to inhibit significantly, that is, all genes obtained a lower abundance than CKG. The abundances of fbaB encoding fructose-bisphosphate aldolase of TIG in the degradation pathway of β-d-fructose-1,6P2 to glyceraldehyde-3P decreased to 0.070‰, which was lower than TDG6 (0.180‰) and CKG1 (0.099‰), indicating that fbaB may be the key gene for resistance to TAN. During the degradation of glycerate-1,3P2 regulated by PGK encoding phosphoglycerate kinase to glycerate-3P, the abundance of TIG (0.885‰) was lower than that of TDG6 (0.890‰) and CKG1 (0.909‰). In this step, TDG also achieved functional gene enrichment. Glycerate-3P was degraded to pyruvate by PGAM, gpmB, apgM, ENO, and PK genes encoding phosphoglycerate mutase, phosphoglycerate mutase, phosphopyruvate hydratase, and pyruvate kinase. The abundance of these genes in TIG was 2.323‰, which was lower than CKG1 (2.646‰) and TDG6 (2.498‰), confirming the tolerance of TDG6 in this step. Additionally, in the acetyl phosphate to acetic acid step regulating by ackA encoding acetate kinase, the abundance of TIG was only 0.736‰, which was lower than that of CKG1 (0.795‰) and TDG6 (0.796‰). The enrichment of genes involved in the above steps (whole process of glycerate-1,3P2 to pyruvate) was confirmed to be the main reason why TDG had tolerance to TAN to produce acetic acid. The abundance of acetyl-CoA regulated by ACSS1_2, which encodes acetyl-CoA synthetase, was also enriched in TDG6.

Therefore, TAN domestication could enrich the genes that regulate the TAN-inhibited pathway from glycerate-1,3P2 to pyruvate and the steps from acetyl-CoA to acetic acid, which may construct a stable acetic acid production process.

Effect of total ammonia nitrogen domestication on CH4 production process

Another important question is which is the main methanogenesis pathway to achieve tolerance to TAN in TDG. Figure 8 shows three pathways for CH4 production revealed by metagenomic analysis. The specific pathway for CH4 production from methanol was the formation of 2-(methylthio)ethanesulfonate under the regulation of methyltransferase encoded by mtaA, mtaB, and mtaC. The abundances of mtaA, mtaB, and mtaC of TIG were only 0.107‰, 0.131‰, and 0.089‰, respectively, which were lower than those in CKG1 (0.131‰, 0.161‰, and 0.091‰) and TDG6 (0.139‰, 0.150‰, and 0.106‰). The abundance of mtaB and mtaC genes in TDG6 was even higher than in CKG1. TAN inhibited the methoxydotrophic methanogenesis but the TAN domestication process achieved gene enrichment.

It was well known that the hydrogenotrophic methanogenesis is a common pathway under inhibition conditions, and its specific pathway was from CO2 to 5,10-methylenetetrahydromethanopterin. The genes involved are given in Fig. 8, and their total abundances in TIG were lower than TDG6 and CKG1, indicating that this pathway also significantly inhibited. Importantly, the abundance of fwdE and hmd genes was up to 0.171‰ and 0.002‰ in TDG6, not only higher than TIG (0.130‰ and 0.001‰), but also higher than in CKG1 (0.154‰ and 0.001‰). With TAN domestication, the hydrogenotrophic methanogenesis was strengthened. The validation experimental data in Fig. S3 further confirms that this pathway has the high potential for CH4 production.

Additionally, the acetoclastic methanogenesis was focused. The specific pathway was from acetate to 5-Methyl-H4MPT regulating by mainly ackA, cdhC, and cdhD genes encoding acetate kinase and acetyl-CoA decarbonylase. Their abundances in TIG were 0.736‰, 0.038‰, and 0.095‰, respectively, which were lower than TDG6 (0.796‰, 0.050‰, and 0.112‰) and CKG1 (0.795‰, 0.052‰, and 0.098‰). This indicated that the acetoclastic methanogenesis in TIG was inhibited but in TDG was enhanced. It is worth noting that the abundance of ACSS1_2 regulating acetate to acetyl-CoA in TDG was as high as 0.947‰, which was higher than 0.896‰ in CKG1. The steps regulated by ACSS1_2 and cdhE may be the main pathways of acetoclastic methanogenesis in TDG under TAN inhibition. This pathway synergistically produces CH4 alongside the hydrogenotrophic methanogenesis confirmed by Fig. S3.

The final CH4 production processes of the three pathways are similar. In the process of 5-Methyl-H4MPT to CH4, mtrC, mtrD, mtrE, mtrF, mtrG, and mtrH genes encoding tetrahydromethanopterin S-methyltransferase were inhibited, and their total abundance in TIG was 0.282‰, which was lower than 0.367‰ in TDG6 and 0.386‰ in CKG1. However, as the final step of methanogenesis, the key genes mcrA, mcrB, and mcrG encoding methyl-CoM reductase were 0.096‰, 0.098‰, and 0.041‰ in TIG, which were lower than TGD6 (0.128‰, 0.127‰, and 0.065‰) and CKG1 (0.148‰, 0.141‰, and 0.070‰). These three genes only existed in methanogens were enriched by TAN domestication process but still lower than CKG1, indicating that it might be an important process limiting CH4 production.

Thus, acetoclastic and hydrogenotrophic methanogenesis was considered both dominant in the TAN domestication system. The step regulated by mcrA, mcrB, and mcrG genes encoding methyl-CoM reductase may well be the key step for CH₄ production.

Mechanism of total ammonia nitrogen domestication to construct a stable synergistic system of acetic acid and CH4 production

Through the above discussion, it is evident that TAN domestication can enhance microbial activity and enrich functional bacteria and genes, but the reasons for these changes need to be considered. The effect size of linear discriminant analysis can reveal the pathways and modules leading to significant differences in AD systems by calculating the score of linear discriminant analysis. The quorum sensing, glycolysis/gluconeogenesis, ABC transporters, amino sugar and nucleotide sugar metabolism, starch and sucrose metabolism, carbon metabolism, pyruvate metabolism and CH4 metabolism in the TAN domestication process were confirmed to be the main reasons for the differences in TDG (Fig. 9a), which indicated that the utilization and transmembrane exchange of small-molecule organic matter, as well as the methanogenic process, were all enhanced. In addition, two-component system also leaded differences during TAN domestication process. The two-component system is a mechanism for bacteria to adapt to the selection pressure by sensing the changes in the external environment, regulating survival and the expression of virulence factors [63]. The two-component system may be a key regulator of organic matter metabolism during the TAN domestication process. However, key metabolic functions involved in methanogenesis did not have high linear discriminant analysis scores in TIG.

Figure 9b shows that the enrichment of lysine biosynthesis module (M00527, M00526, M00525, and M00016) provided a contribution to the differences among the samples in TDG. Lysine is a widely used amino acid involved in protein synthesis and energy metabolism [64], and the enrichment of its metabolic module indicated that microbial activity was enhanced. The glycolysis/gluconeogenesis (M00001, M00003, and M00002) was enriched, indicating that the hydrolytic and acidogenic process was promoted. In addition, the high abundance of pyruvate oxidation (M00307) indicated that the acetogenic process was strengthened. Figure 9b does not indicate other high abundance microbial metabolic modules with high differential contribution in TIG, indicating that microbial metabolic function of TIG was weak. Thus, this further confirms that the two-component system during TAN domestication maintained microbial metabolic activity, thereby achieving stable CH₄ production under ultra-high TAN inhibition.

As shown in the Fig. 9c, the microbial mechanisms by which TAN domestication alleviates inhibition are summarized. Specifically, the AD system process gradually adapted to the increasing TAN concentration by enriching the two-component system to regulate microbial metabolism and collaborative network in TAN domestication process. In this process, microbial activity was improved, and hydrolytic and acidogenic bacteria dominated by MBA03_unclassified and archaea dominated by Methanosarcina were enriched. In addition, the TAN-inhibited steps of acetic acid production (from glycerate-1,3P2 to pyruvate and from acetyl-CoA and acetyl phosphate to acetic acid) and CH4 production [from 2-(methylthio)ethanesulfonate to CH4] processes were also alleviated. These reasons together led to the stable production of CH4 in TAN domestication. However, TIG did not produce CH4 because an ultra-high concentration of TAN completely inhibited microbial activity, acetic acid production and methanogenesis.

Engineering application potential and implications

To evaluate the application potential of TAN domesticated AD system, the Minhe biogas plant (Fig. 10a, b), with 24,000 m3 operation scale, was used to compare with the TAN domesticated AD system. As shown in Fig. 10c, in the biogas plant, the concentration of TAN was 5688.32 mg/L, and the concentration of COD was 32,690 mg/L. The concentration of TAN and organic matter was similar to the TAN domesticated system in this study. In addition, the microbial community composition were hydrolytic and acidogenic genera Fastidiosipila [65] (26.09%), Caldicoprobacter (5.08%), DTU014_unclassified (3.79%), Lachnospiraceae_unclassified [66] (2.14%), Proteiniphilum (1.97%), Butyrivibrio [66] (1.89%), Clostridium [67] (1.76%), and HN-HF0106 (1.76%) (Fig. S6a), holding the similar functions with TDG (Fig. 10d). Also, its archaea community was mainly composed of Methanosarcina (0.30%), Methanoculleus (19.36%), Methanobacterium (0.02%), Methanobrevibacter (77.99%) and Methanothrix (0.16%) (Fig. S6b). Both the Minhe biogas project and the TDG-enriched methanogens under TAN stress (Fig. 10e), and the hydrogenotrophic methanogen Methanobrevibacter further confirms that a hydrogenotrophic methanogenesis similar to that of TDG has been enriched.

Previous studies by Schnürer et al. [68, 69] have confirmed that high concentrations of TAN exert significant stress on microbial communities and driving the stress-resistant remodeling of community succession is a key strategy to achieve methanogenesis. The similar TAN load and microbial community functions of this biogas plant practically confirms the application potential of domesticated AD system developed in this study. Although the CH4 production in this study was only 72.81 mL/g VS, which is lower than the 310 mL/g VS of the Minhe biogas plant. This is mainly because the lower substrate load, as a limiting factor [70], hinders higher CH4 production. However, after applying this strategy to the plant, the use of higher substrate loads is likely to generate more CH4. This study has the potential to increase the CH₄ production per unit of substrate, thereby demonstrating promising application prospects for enhancing economic efficiency.
